top_comment.text: I feel like #1 should be every christmas song ever﻿
top_comment.author: Heather Renklauf

comments.text:
+MartianSanta Presumably you're referring to the fact that the majority of 
Christmas songs are "traditional" songs that predate recording technology, 
so there is no one recording that is definitively the original.

There are many Christmas songs that are more modern compositions, so we can 
speak of covers of them in the usual sense. Examples (with their original 
performers): Jingle Bell Rock (Bobby Helms), Santa Baby (Eartha Kitt), 
Christmas Wrapping (The Waitresses), The Little Drummer Boy (The Trapp 
Family Singers, NOT the Harry Simeone Chorale; that version is a cover, as 
is the later Bing Crosby/David Bowie duet), and (heaven help us) The 
Christmas Shoes (NewSong).
comments.author: Shirley Márquez Dúlcey

comments.text:
We both may actually be correct. The definition of a cover is a new 
performance or recording of a previously recorded, commercially released, 
or unreleased, song, by someone other than the original artist or composer. 
The operative word being 'commercially' invalidates happy birthday - but in 
the other instances you're correct.

top_comment.text:
"My way" was actually a 1967 french song sang by Claude Francois the name 
of the song in french was "Comme D'habitude" which translate to "As Usual" 
the first english adaptation of the song was made by David Bowie in 1968 it 
was called "Even a Fool Learns to Love" but never became a big success, 
then in 1969 Paul Anka bought the rights to the song for Frank Sinatra.﻿
top_comment.author: Gordon Pattison

comments.text:
Ok buddy, have it your way. Recording a new version of a song, with 
different lyrics, is "an early form of sampling". Bye now
comments.author: Everybody's Dead Dave

comments.text:
There is a huge difference between a cover and scraping more than half the 
song and making a new one. None of the lyrics are the same, the music 
itself had been changed to fit a new tune, and at that point in time it 
might as well have been an early from of sampling
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

comments.text:
"My way" does NOT contain any bits from the recording of "Comme 
d'habitude", but it does use the same notes and chords. Just like Guns N' 
Roses' version of "Knockin' on heaven's door" does not sample Bob Dylan's 
original recording, or even sound similar, but no one would deny they are 
the same song.
comments.author: Everybody's Dead Dave

comments.text:
"Sampling" is when you reuse bits of music already recorded by someone else 
and then add other bits - as opposed to (re)creating those notes with 
musical instruments.
comments.author: Everybody's Dead Dave

comments.text:
+Everybody's Dead Dave Using a portion of a back ground track is sampling 
correct? Since My way took the original work and added to it it is called 
SAMPLING.
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

comments.text:
(Also, why does everyone always bring up "u can't touch this" and "ice ice 
baby" as if they're the only songs ever? There are thousands of - mainly 
hip hop - songs that lifted their hook from an older hit song)
comments.author: Everybody's Dead Dave

comments.text:
No, no, no. I'm afraid the difference between "covering" a song and 
"sampling" from it is lost on you. "My way" does not sample from "Comme 
d'habitude" so I don't see what this has anything to do with it.
comments.author: Everybody's Dead Dave

comments.text:
+Everybody's Dead Dave Buy the rights to a song's music and you can. That's 
how it works. With music there is this magical thing called being 
unoriginal. It has been something since the dawn of music. Do we call Ice 
Ice Baby  "Under Pressure? No, they are two different songs. Is Super Freak 
now also Can't Touch This? No, different songs. It's the same situation, 
borrowed or in this case bought music and new lyrics.
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

comments.text:
+Everybody's Dead Dave I totally agree. Putting new lyrics to an existing 
tune doesn't make it a new song.
comments.author: George Oblin

comments.text:
+ViolentSeizurez By your reasoning I could record, say, "knocking on 
heaven's door" with different lyrics, and call it my own. And what it has 
to do with sampling is beyond me, that's pretty much the opposite to what 
"My way" did to "Comme d'habitude". "My way" is a cover of "Comme 
d'habitude", just like for example "Cette annéé-là" by the same Claude 
François is a cover of "December 63".
comments.author: Everybody's Dead Dave

comments.text: sid's version is cool
comments.author: Aurelien Barriol (Aurelstuf)

comments.text:
+George Oblin With how much was changed and how much was left, at this 
level it might as well be called sampling. Sampling from another song 
doesn't make it the same song. I shouldn't have said whole new song, but it 
for sure is not the same song as Comme D'habitude
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

comments.text:
+ViolentSeizurez Respectfully it isn't a whole new song when the melody is 
identical to the original version even if the lyrics are different.
comments.author: George Oblin

comments.text:
+Gordon Pattison It was not translated. It was the lyrics were scrapped 
because Paul Anka thought the original sucked. So he bought the rights, 
gave it better lyrics, tweaked it a bit and made it a whole new song.
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

comments.text:
+ViolentSeizurez
Je connais les deux chanson par cœur, tu peut pas prendre une chanson 
française et la traduire littéralement en français la chanson ne feras 
aucun sens, c'est comme essayer d'expliquer pourquoi une chaise est au 
féminin et un banc est au masculin ou essayer d'expliquer le terme être 
dans la lune a un anglais, il y a plusieurs chose qui ne se traduise pas et 
c'est pour ça que la chanson a du être traduit pour faire plus de sens.
comments.author: Gordon Pattison

comments.text:
Literally. There is NOTHING the same about they lyrics.

Comme d'habitude (translated)

"I get out of bed
And I bump into you
It doesn't wake you up
As usual

I pull the sheet up
Over you
Afraid you might be cold
As usual

My hand
Strokes your hair
Almost unwillingly
As usual

But you
You turn your back on me
As usual

And then
I dress up quickly
I get out of the room
As usual

All on my own
I drink my coffee
I'm late at work
As usual

Without a noise
I leave the house
It's all grey outside
As usual

I'm cold
I turn up my collar
As usual

As usual
All day long
Like it's a game
I'll be pretending

As usual
I'll be smiling
Yeah, as usual
I'll even be laughing
As usual
I'll live at last
Yeah, as usual

And then
Day will go
But I'll come back
As usual

You
You'll be out already
Not home yet
As usual

All on my own
I'll go to sleep
In this big cold bed
As usual

My tears
I will cover
As usual

As usual
Even at night
Like it's a game
I'll be pretending

As usual
You'll come back home
As usual
I'll be waiting
As usual
You'll be smiling at me
Yeah, as usual

As usual
You'll get undressed
As usual
You'll go to bed
Yeah, as usual
And we'll kiss
As usual

As usual
We will pretend
Yeah, as usual
We'll make love
Yeah, as usual
We will pretend
Yeah, as usual.."

My Way

"And now, the end is near
And so I face the final curtain
My friend, I'll say it clear
I'll state my case, of which I'm certain
I've lived a life that's full
I traveled each and ev'ry highway
And more, much more than this, I did it my way

Regrets, I've had a few
But then again, too few to mention
I did what I had to do , I saw it through without exemption
I planned each charted course, each careful step along the highway
And more, much more than this, I did it my way

Yes, there were times, I'm sure you knew
When I bit off more than I could chew
And through it all, when there was doubt
I ate it up and spit it out
I faced it all and I stood tall and did it my way

I've loved, I've laughed and cried
I've had my fill, my share of losing
And now, as tears subside, I find it all so amusing
To think I did all that
And may I say, not in a shy way,
"Oh, no, oh, no, not me, I did it my way"

For what is a man, what has he got?
If not himself, then he has naught
The right to say the things he feels and not the words of one who kneels
The record shows I took the blows and did it my way!"
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

comments.text:
+ViolentSeizurez
Unlike Ice Ice Baby and Under Pressure the lyrics of My Way are based on 
the lyrics of Comme D'habitude, in the song Claude Francois sings about 
doing things with is girlfriend his way like usual, being Canadian I been 
speaking french and english all my life I can detect the similarities 
between the two songs.
comments.author: Gordon Pattison

comments.text:
The words that Frank sings actually unrealated to the french song lyrics. 
Only the tune was saved. So that makes it a different song. Just like how 
"Ice Ice baby" is not "Under Pressure".
comments.author: Icy Knuckles

captions.text: We really don't need to hear another version of these.
Welcome to WatchMojo.com,
and today we're counting down our picks for the top 10 over-covered songs.
For this list, we’re not only considering how many times the songs have been covered,
but are also taking into account how clichéd it is to cover them,
as well as their overall popularity and pop culture impact.
After Little Willie John made this a number-one R&B hit in 1956,
Peggy Lee knew she couldn't pass on the chance to make it hers.
'Fever' became a top ten smash and her signature number despite the modified lyrics.
Through genres like jazz, rock and roll, pop, dance and soul,
artists like Elvis Presley, Madonna,
Beyoncé and more have all thought 'Fever' is a 'lovely way to burn'.
It's unlikely anyone will ever manage to capture Judy Garland's innocence
and wishful thinking in 'The Wizard of Oz'.
In fact, the Oscar-winning ballad even became an American symbol during the Second World War,
and one of the most beloved movie songs ever.
Though Frank Sinatra, Doris Day, Tony Bennett, Ella Fitzgerald and others have covered the track,
Israel Kamakawiwo'ole and Eva Cassidy truly made it their own.
It was for the 1935 opera, 'Porgy and Bess',
that George Gershwin and DuBose Heyword wrote the aria 'Summertime'.
With its jazz and southern African-American influences,
it's become a music standard that's prompted thousands of covers.
Following Abbie Mitchell's recording, Billie Holiday had a top 20 hit,
but Billy Stewart bested that by making the Billboard Hot 100's top 10.
The song's also found its way into psychedelic rock, R&B, soul,
alternative hip hop, ska punk and more.
Since Cohen's 1984 release of the folk ballad,
'Hallelujah' has undergone many transformations:
John Cale's serious version contrasted joy and sorrow,
Jeff Buckley magnified the song's emotional reach with haunting beauty,
and Rufus Wainwright produced a more piano-heavy take.
Today, artists continue bringing the song to life,
with reality show performances most notably reviving its popularity on the charts
over two decades after its initial release.
First recorded by The Top Notes as 'Shake It Up, Baby', this rock 'n' roll tune
gave The Isley Brothers crossover success in the 1960s.
But it was The Beatles' rough-and-ready take that exemplified British rock and roll
by taking shouting to a new level.
Aside from being a live staple for The Who and Bruce Springsteen,
the song's also had makeovers in reggae, folk, rap and more.
As its original composer and recording artist,
Richard Berry found moderate success with his ballad version in the late 1950s.
But it was with The Kingsmen's Jamaican flavors,
memorable riff and rock 'n' roll rhythm that 'Louie Louie'
truly became engrained in musical consciousness.
Now considered a standard, their 1963 rendition paved the way for folk,
hard rock, heavy metal and even hardcore punk versions to emerge.
By encouraging us to dream, 'Imagine' became John Lennon's best-selling single as a solo artist.
Thanks to its universal message of hope and world peace,
it quickly found both critical and commercial success.
It's also inspired artists to cover it the world over,
ranging from high profile acts like Elton John, Madonna, Stevie Wonder,
Neil Young and Queen, to up-and-comers like Emeli Sandé.
It's gone from an 18th century Christian hymn to American musical icon.
Despite themes of mercy and salvation,
its lyrics have also given non-religious folks hope and inspiration
and made it one of the most well-known songs in the English language.
Particularly associated with African Americans and church services,
'Amazing Grace' has been covered by Elvis Presley,
Billy 'Crash' Craddock, Joan Baez, Susan Boyle and more.
This Paul Anka number achieved fame thanks to its confident lyrics and Frank Sinatra's crooning.
While its record-setting 75 weeks within the UK Top 40 showed it connected with audiences,
its multiple cover versions are what earned 'My Way' a place in music history.
Despite being a traditional pop tune,
it has found success with artists ranging from Elvis Presley to the Sex Pistols.
Since they're arguably the world's most covered band,
it's no surprise that one of their tunes lands at number one.
Though the single topped American charts in 1965,
it didn't actually come out at home until 1976.
The UK was only introduced to the melancholy melody
by Matt Monro three months after its U.S. release.
'Yesterday' has since been recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records
as one of the most recorded songs ever.
Do you agree with our list?
What song do you think is covered too often?
Be sure to subscribe to WatchMojo.com for more entertaining top 10s.
Subtitles by the Amara.org community
